awd_titl_txt: Experimental and Computational Investigation of Fracture Propagation in Rocks
awd_abstract_narration:
A thorough understanding of why, when and where rock fractures initiate, propagate and coalesce is of critical importance in the stability of rock structures such as slopes, foundations, and tunnels, as well as processes involving blasting and hydraulic fracture.  This project will involve advanced laboratory testing of fracture in rock samples that will provide data on material behavior for use in computational models that can be used in a predictive capacity.  The deliverables of this project will allow civil and geotechnical engineers to perform safer and more economical designs that will benefit society across a broad range of applications.  The research will be integrated with educational and outreach activities.  The interdisciplinary nature of this project, including experimental rock mechanics and computational geomechanics, will provide outstanding educational and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students at the Colorado School of Mines (CSM).  The researchers will encourage the participation of underrepresented groups on this project, e.g. through the Society of Women Engineers (SWE) and Multicultural Engineering Program (MEP) student organizations on the CSM campus.  They   will also develop, implement, and assess instructional hands-on modules on materials behavior to be delivered during workshops.  The research findings will be incorporated into graduate and undergraduate courses and disseminated through conference and journal articles. 


The goal of this research project is to discover the fracturing characteristics of natural rocks with different pre-existing flaw geometries.  The research objective is to formulate new experimentally verified crack initiation and propagation criteria that can be applied to different rocks with different flaw geometries for implementation in advanced numerical codes.  A key innovation in this project is the combined mechanical-geophysical-numerical investigation of the fracturing processes in natural rocks.  A comprehensive suite of uniaxial compression experiments will be conducted on granite, limestone, and sandstone with pre-existing flaws, with synergistic use of acoustic emission and active geophysical (ultrasonic) monitoring techniques.  Based on experimental observations, new fracture initiation criteria will be developed and implemented in an eXtended Finite Element Method (XFEM) code to provide an entirely novel and potentially transformative numerical tool for assessment and prediction of fracturing in anisotropic rock formations.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding rock fracturing is a matter of fundamental importance in rock engineering due to its applications in underground structures, rock slopes, rock bursts in mining, and hydraulic fracturing. Fracturing in quasi-brittle materials such as rocks is characterized by an inelastic deformation at the tip of pre-existing flaws, which occurs due to the formation of a micro-cracking zone, also known as the fracture process zone (FPZ). The common practice in existing research involves neglecting the effect of FPZ by assuming elastic stress distribution around the tip of pre-existing flaws. This often leads to large inconsistencies in the fracture properties, such as fracture toughness and tensile strength obtained from different testing geometries and loading configurations. The inconsistency in fracture properties also limits the applicability of existing crack initiation criteria in rocks, especially under different loading conditions. Therefore, a comprehensive characterization of the FPZ is crucial for understanding the cracking mechanism in rocks and developing reliable crack criteria that will allow for a better assessment of the stability of rock structures.

In our research, we have characterized the FPZ development in rocks, using a combination of experimental testing and numerical simulation, that allows for the development of analysis tools to then reliably predict critical conditions for fracture initiation in rocks. Using the 2D-Digital Image Correlation (2D-DIC) technique, we investigated the influence of the FPZ in pre-cracked laboratory-scale rock specimens under mode I and mode II loading conditions. Through direct measurements of the local displacements inside the FPZ, we developed a novel methodology that characterized the evolution of FPZ under various loading conditions. This methodology involved analyzing the variation of crack opening displacement and sliding displacement at the location of FPZ initiation and provided explicit evidence of fracture mode and identified suitable constitutive models for material softening inside the FPZ. The work also showed that most mode II geometries do not result in a pure mode II fracture until a high level of confinement is applied to the specimen. Additionally, the short beam in compression was identified as a more suitable alternative geometry for estimating mode II fracture toughness than the commonly used punch through shear testing configuration.

XFEM-based numerical models were used in this research to validate the constitutive models used for simulating FPZ development in quasi-brittle materials, due to their ability to model the crack propagation without the need for remeshing. A novel XFEM-based user element was developed with the capability to model FPZ development in various crack types, especially in compression-induced shear cracks. This was done by implementing a new constitutive model that accounted for both cohesion degradation and frictional sliding in propagating shear cracks. The XFEM-based user element, through the implementation of advanced branching algorithms, is now able to simulate multiple crack types from the body of pre-existing cracks, thereby removing the limitation of traditional XFEM models. As a result, the XFEM-based user element can reliably predict paths of secondary cracks along with crack coalescence mechanisms in specimens subjected to compression loading.
